keyword.value: UNCITRAL Model Law on Automated Contracting
keyword.showAs: UNCITRAL Model Law on Automated Contracting
Report of the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law on the work of its 57th session.
keyword.shortForm: UN COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW--REPORTS

step.by: the representative of Viet Nam, on behalf of the Bureau

p.inline: Report of the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law on the work of its fifty-seventh session

p.docTitle: Resolution adopted by the General Assembly on 4 December 2024

p.docProponent: [on the report of the Sixth Committee (A/79/467, para. 11)]

container.name: Recalling
container.p: Recalling its resolution 2205 (XXI) of 17 December 1966, by which it established the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law with a mandate to further the progressive harmonization and unification of the law of international trade and in that respect to bear in mind the interests of all peoples, in particular those of developing countries, in the extensive development of international trade,

container.name: Recalling also
container.p: Recalling also its resolution 60/21 of 23 November 2005, by which it adopted the United Nations Convention on the Use of Electronic Communications in International Contracts and called upon all Governments to consider becoming party to the Convention, and its resolutions 51/162 of 16 December 1996, 56/80 of 12 December 2001, 72/114 of 7 December 2017 and 77/101 of 7 December 2022, in which it recommended that all States give favourable consideration to the Model Law on Electronic Commerce, the Model Law on Electronic Signatures, the Model Law on Electronic Transferable Records and the Model Law on the Use and Cross-border Recognition of Identity Management and Trust Services of the Commission, respectively,

container.name: Mindful
container.p: Mindful that the Convention, the Model Law on Electronic Commerce, the Model Law on Electronic Signatures, the Model Law on Electronic Transferable Records and the Model Law on the Use and Cross-border Recognition of Identity Management and Trust Services are of significant assistance to States in enabling and facilitating electronic commerce in international trade,

container.name: Mindful also
container.p: Mindful also of the importance of providing a legal foundation to promote confidence in electronic commerce, including across borders, and of the increasing relevance of automation in contracting, including through the deployment of artificial intelligence systems,

container.name: Considering
container.p: Considering that uncertainty as to the legal effect of automation in contracting can create an obstacle to harnessing the full potential of digital trade,

container.name: Convinced
container.p: Convinced that legal certainty and commercial predictability in electronic commerce, including across borders, will be enhanced by the harmonization of certain rules on the use of automation in contracting on a technologically neutral basis,

container.name: Recalling
container.p:
Recalling that the Commission placed the topic of automated contracting on its work programme at its fifty-fourth session, in 2021,
Official Records of the General Assembly, Seventy-sixth Session, Supplement No. 17 (A/76/17), paras. 25 (e) and 236. and referred the topic to its Working Group IV (Electronic Commerce) at its fifty-fifth session, in 2022,
Ibid., Seventy-seventh Session, Supplement No. 17 (A/77/17), para. 22 (d).

container.name: Noting
container.p:
Noting that the Working Group devoted three sessions, in 2022 and 2023, to that work, and that the Commission considered at its fifty-seventh session, in 2024, draft provisions on automated contracting prepared at the request of the Working Group,
Ibid., Seventy-ninth Session, Supplement No. 17 (A/79/17), chap. VII.

container.name: Believing
container.p: Believing that a model law on automated contracting will constitute a useful addition to existing Commission texts in the area of electronic commerce by assisting States in enhancing their legislation governing the use of automation in contracting, or in formulating such legislation where none exists,

content.p:
Expresses its appreciation to the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law for completing and adopting the Model Law on Automated Contracting;
Ibid., annex IV.

Requests the Secretary-General to publish the Model Law together with a guide to the enactment thereof, including electronically, in the six official languages of the United Nations, and to disseminate it broadly to Governments and other interested bodies;

Recommends that all States give favourable consideration to the Model Law when revising or adopting legislation on electronic commerce, and invites States that have used the Model Law to advise the Commission accordingly;

Also recommends that States continue to consider becoming parties to the United Nations Convention on the Use of Electronic Communications in International Contracts
United Nations, Treaty Series, vol. 2898, No. 50525. and to give favourable consideration to the Model Law on Electronic Commerce,
Resolution 51/162, annex. the Model Law on Electronic Signatures,
Resolution 56/80, annex. the Model Law on Electronic Transferable Records
Official Records of the General Assembly, Seventy-second Session, Supplement No. 17 (A/72/17), annex I. and the Model Law on the Use and Cross-border Recognition of Identity Management and Trust Services
Ibid., Seventy-seventh Session, Supplement No. 17 (A/77/17), annex II. when revising or adopting legislation on electronic commerce;

Appeals to the relevant bodies of the United Nations system and other relevant international and regional organizations to coordinate their legal activities in the area of electronic commerce with those of the Commission, to avoid duplication of efforts and to promote efficiency, consistency and coherence in the modernization and harmonization of legislation on electronic commerce.
